text: Happy Women's History Month! Each week I'll be highlighting one of the many amazing Kansas women who’ve made history, starting with Amelia Earhart. Born in Atchison, she became a groundbreaking aviator and the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean.
Healthcare is on the ballot this election, and if GOP leadership gets its way, Kansans with pre-existing conditions will no longer be protected. It's time to send a doctor to Washington.

Just like Gov. Brownback’s tax experiment failed to generate significant economic growth in Kansas, the national GOP’s huge giveaways aren’t working either.  We can’t just bankrupt our children’s future so special interests can keep extra cash in their accounts.
The prospect of helping 130,000 Kansans get health insurance is worth far more than a politician trying to score political points.
Mitch McConnell has a bill on his desk right now that would lower prices on insulin and other prescription drugs for all Americans. We need to do this now.
There’s a role for government to play in helping address this tragic trend. As a doctor, I promise to bring compassion and facts to policymaking in the U.S. Senate.

Katherine Johnson was a trailblazer for women in science and showed especially that black women can do anything they set their mind to. I remember when I was at University of Kansas Medical School in the 1980s being constantly confronted by classmates and professors who didn't think a woman belonged there. It must have been all the more difficult for Ms. Johnson 30 years prior when she began at NASA's precursor. She faced down sexism and racism and became one of the foundations of our space program. She will be missed.

Kansas is one of the worst states for surprise medical billing. This often happens when health insurance and providers can’t agree on pricing, so the patient gets stuck with the difference. My legislation would require them to leave the patient out of it. It’s a commonsense solution that will keep working families out of medical debt.

Republican leadership in the state legislature is playing games with Kansas families' healthcare. There is a bipartisan majority to expand Medicaid so 130,000 more Kansans can get covered, but GOP leaders will stop at nothing to block it.

Republican leadership in the state legislature is playing games with Kansas families' healthcare. There is a bipartisan majority to expand Medicaid so 130,000 more Kansans can get covered, but GOP leaders will stop at nothing to block it.

When I think about what public service really means to me, I always come back to the legacy of Senator Nancy Kassebaum. For those who don’t know, she was the first woman elected to a full term in the U.S. Senate in her own right, and the first female Senator from Kansas. My mom was a big supporter of Nancy’s, and did some work to help her get elected. We discussed her leadership a lot in my house growing up, and she’s someone I admire to this day.  In the Senate, Nancy was an independent thinker who worked across the aisle to get things done for Kansans.  She always put us first. That’s the kind of Senator I’ll be, too. She was an original co-sponsor of HIPAA, the landmark bipartisan legislation that protects patients’ private health information. As a doctor, I’ve seen firsthand just how important Nancy’s work is to people all over the country. And that’s only the beginning.  We’re all tired of career politicians — Nancy wasn’t one. When she felt she could help Kansans, she put her hat in the ring. And when she felt her time could be better spent as a grandmother, she gracefully retired. With Nancy as a trailblazer, Kansas is ready to elect the first female physician to the U.S. Senate.

In Wichita this afternoon, we discussed how important it is to think of climate change as a public health issue. If we don’t take immediate steps to address it, folks with asthma will see worsening symptoms, for example. Thanks to everyone that came out!

Today I visited with Kansans in El Dorado and Hutchinson. I heard about the importance of international trade for our ag producers, social security for our seniors and healthcare for all of us. In the U.S. Senate, I‘ll work to protect and expand all of those.

Kansas' GOP leadership is continuing their lawsuit to eliminate protections for pre-existing conditions, the ban on lifetime limits and the ability to keep dependents on health insurance until they're 26, even as the law that enacted them is now at record high popularity. As a doctor, I'll never play politics with your healthcare.

Even with health insurance, I once ended up with a $30,000 medical bill — way more than I expected and than my out-of-pocket maximum. That’s outrageous and costs like it are a reason why I’m sponsoring legislation to end surprise medical billing in Kansas.
Wichitans, let's chat over coffee this weekend!

Kansas has dropped 17 places in health rankings since 1990. As a doctor, I value the health of all Kansans. That’s why I support expanding Medicaid. Access to affordable healthcare is a basic human right.
Republican leadership will stop at nothing to block Medicaid expansion. The result? 130,000 Kansans will continue to go without healthcare and rural hospitals will continue to struggle.

Earlier this week I visited the VFW hall in Emporia and the energy was absolutely electric. It was wonderful to see both Republicans and Democrats fired up to send a voice of reason to the Senate. Thanks to the Lyon County Democratic Party for hosting!

Today, on the anniversary of the tragic Parkland shooting, the deadliest high school shooting in history, we remember those killed. We can’t just mourn, though — we must recommit to ending gun violence in this country. Attending the March For Our Lives two years ago, I was inspired by the students and their families’ refusal to let violence scare them away from standing up for their beliefs. Our children deserve safety.

Kansas’ rural hospitals are in crisis — two thirds of them operate in the red according to an investigation by the Pittsburg Morning Sun. One of many reasons I’ve spent years advocating for Medicaid expansion.

This is outrageous. Our healthcare system is so broken that Kansans like Tres Biggs are going to jail due to medical debt. His family hasn’t been able to pay off bills they accrued because of cancer and lyme disease, despite him working two jobs.
A new poll just came out showing our race TIED. Together, we can flip this seat, find common sense solutions and give Kansans a voice of reason in the Senate. Contribute now:
Susan Wagle didn't get what she wanted so she's blocking Medicaid expansion and endangering the lives of 130,000 Kansans. Susan Wagle is not the steady hand Kansas needs in the U.S. Senate.

After hours of bullying, GOP leadership failed to slip a constitutional amendment restricting women’s rights onto the August primary ballot — where far fewer Kansans typically vote. I’m proud to have stood against this amendment in the State Senate. Women should be able to make healthcare decisions with their doctors, not the government.

For many Kansans, this economy just isn’t working. In the past decade, we’ve gone from having the 21st highest average weekly wage to the 42nd. That means working families are having a harder time keeping food on their tables.

Happy birthday to my husband Rene! Glad he’s finally caught up to me — I’ve been the older woman for three whole weeks. But seriously, he’s my role model. He’s hard working, supportive and so deeply caring. I couldn’t ask for a more incredible partner.
Rene and I are rooting hard for The Kansas City Chiefs today! Let’s beat the 49ers!
As a physician, I’d never make a medical decision without all the facts, so not wanting to hear all the relevant facts and witnesses is unimaginable to me. It’s time to check Mitch McConnell’s power:
Kansas is an ag state and our family farmers are in crisis. Yes, this has been a long-running trend, but recent trade policies certainly aren't helping.

It was such an honor to join the Shawnee County Democrats at their annual Bean Feed last weekend.  After I spoke, I joined a high school student and his parents for a meal — we discussed the importance of getting engaged with government at an early age.

The Kansas Constitution should not put politicians between women and their doctors, especially when difficult, personal medical decisions need to be made. I oppose limiting women’s access to basic healthcare. I oppose this amendment.
Happy Kansas Day! 159 years ago, Kansas was admitted to the Union.

I’m spending a lot of time in Topeka since we’re in a legislative session at the moment, but I’ve still been able to meet folks around the state. It’s so exciting to spread our message of bringing reason to Washington.

It’s January 28 and Republicans are already up on TV lying about my record — 280 days out from the election. Kansans deserve better than lying politicians. We've got to set the record straight. Can you chip in to help us respond and defeat them?

As anti-Semitism continues to endanger Jews around the world, we honor and remember those murdered by the Nazis. This Holocaust Memorial Day, the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, I’m recommitting to the fight against discrimination and injustice in all its forms.On January 27, 1945 the German Nazi concentration and extermination Auschwitz-Birkenau camp was liberated. Today we commemorate the 75th anniversary of this event. At around 9 a.m. the first Soviet soldier from a reconnaissance unit of the 100th Infantry Division appeared on the grounds of the prisoners' infirmary in Monowitz. The entire division arrived half an hour later. The same day a military doctor arrived and began to organize assistance. In the afternoon soldiers of the Red Army entered the vicinity of the Auschwitz main camp and Birkenau. Near the main camp they met resistance from retreating German units. 231 Red Army soldiers died in close combat for the liberation of Auschwitz, Birkenau and Monowitz. Two of them died in front of the gates of Auschwitz main camp. One of them was Lieutenant Gilmudin Badryjewicz Baszirow. The first Red Army troops arrived in Birkenau and Auschwitz at around 3 p.m. and were joyfully greeted by the liberated prisoners. After the removal of mines from the surrounding area, soldiers of the 60th Army of the 1st Ukrainian Front marched into the camp and brought freedom to the prisoners who were still alive. On the grounds of the main camp were 48 corpses and in Birkenau over 600 corpses of male and female prisoners who were shot or died in the last few days. At the time of the Red Army's arrival there were 7,000 sick and exhausted prisoners in the Auschwitz, Birkenau and Monowitz camps. Online lesson about the evacuation and the liberation of Auschwitz: http://lekcja.auschwitz.org/en_11_wyzwolenie/

Thanks to Equality Kansas for inviting me to speak at Equality Day. My bipartisan bill to outlaw LGBTQ discrimination in Kansas is so close to becoming law — we've got 18 co-sponsors in the State Senate and we need just 21 votes for it to pass.

Today, on the 47th anniversary of Roe vs. Wade, the Kansas Legislature is yet again trying to legislate women's healthcare decisions. As a mom, doctor and elected official, I'll tell you this: Governments have no business getting between women and their providers.

This campaign is all about building a grassroots movement here in Kansas to bring reason back to Washington. If you’re a student who’s ready to help lead this team, apply to join our fellowship program: https://bit.ly/bbfellow

Last year, I had the opportunity to go to the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis. The entire museum was breathtaking, but I was particularly inspired by Movement to Overcome, the massive bronze sculpture that sits in the lobby. It shows thousands of people physically supporting each other in order to get over a barrier.  Martin Luther King Jr.’s positive message of using nonviolence to pursue equity even in the face of violent racism and hate, must still resonate. Like the figures in the sculpture, we must support one another to build the more equitable world he spent his life fighting for.

Had a great time speaking with folks in Iola yesterday about the need to send a problem solver, not a partisan, to the Senate. The barista made a joke about Kansas trying to kill us every winter and the opossum we almost hit in the ice storm on the way there really proved that.
In Pittsburg this morning we discussed how important it is for Kansas working families to have access to childcare. Thanks to everyone for coming out this chilly, rainy morning!
I first ran for office because, as a physician, I think that people making healthcare policy should know something about it. That's what I told Michael Hayslip KOAM this morning.
Thanks to the Labette County Democrats and everyone in Parsons for joining me to discuss agriculture, healthcare and other issues critical to Kansas this evening!

I'm so proud of all of the work Laura Kelly has done to fully fund education, improve our infrastructure and restore the state's financial footing. This year, I'll work hand-in-hand with her and a bipartisan coalition to finally get KanCare expansion done because Kansans deserve affordable healthcare.
Excited to see the Labette County Democrats tomorrow at their January meeting. I hope you'll join us if you can!
Boeing’s fired CEO walked away with $62 million, while workers in Wichita are suffering because of his and Boeing’s recklessness. This is so deeply wrong and shows just how broken our system is.

Kansas is among the worst states for surprise medical billing. This legislative session, I'll introduce a bill to end the practice and protect working families. I look forward to working across party and ideological lines to protect Kansans from medical debt.
Join me in Pittsburg on Friday morning at Root Coffeehouse!
I'll be grabbing coffee in Iola on Friday morning. I'd love to see you there!
Not only is today the first day of the legislative session, but it's also my birthday. My team surprised me by decorating my office in Topeka. Thanks to everyone for the kind wishes!

"In private polling, Republicans have [Kris] Kobach losing to likely Democratic nominee Barbara Bollier, and Kobach leading every other Republican in a head-to-head..."  That's what I read in The Cook Political Report yesterday. Chip in to continue our momentum:

My thoughts are with the Kansans who are being impacted by the Spirit layoffs. I'll be in touch with the working families affected, community leaders and state leaders to determine what Kansas can do to help them during this difficult time. Quality assurance and responsible regulation matter. Hardworking Kansans shouldn't be paying the price for the failures of government and corporations.
I may not be a Republican anymore, but my values and commitment to affordable health care remains the same. Here's a throwback to when Gov. Brownback vetoed Medicaid expansion in 2017.

Laura Kelly and I have been fighting together for Medicaid expansion for years. I'm so proud of her for getting us this far. I'll be working hard this legislative session to finally get KanCare expansion done. It'll be a huge boon to Kansas working families and our economy.I am very pleased to announce today that in true bipartisan fashion, Senate Majority Leader Jim Denning and I reached a compromise proposal to expand Medicaid while lowering health insurance premiums for Kansas families across the state. I'm so proud of this team for the incredible work we've done together. We had the best first quarter of any Kansas Democratic candidate ever. Having you on my team makes me so thankful.

Kansans are ready to send a voice of reason to the Senate, and the numbers prove it. We raised over $1.1 million during our first quarter in the race, thanks in no small part to your support! That’s more than double any Kansas Democrat has ever raised in a Senate campaign. It’s such an honor to have you on this grassroots team.
We need to build on what's working when it comes to healthcare. That's why I've long led the fight to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act.

It goes without saying, we do not mourn the death of Qasem Soleimani. He was a ruthless killer, responsible for the deaths of hundreds of Americans.  Now that the Trump Administration has taken this action, it’s important for the administration to demonstrate to the American people that there is a thoughtful and strategic plan to prevent this from escalating into yet another war.  My hope is that the Trump Administration will work with Congress and our allies around the globe to ensure that Americans at home and abroad are safe.
This evening I spoke with the Johnson County Democratic Women North about my run for Senate and the coming legislative session. I’m confident we’ll finally be able to get KanCare expansion done.

The wealthy are thriving, while the middle class is left behind. It’s deeply troubling to me that Republicans chose to turn their tax reform bill into a huge giveaway to the ultra-rich and corporations. I’ll always put Kansas middle class families first.
In 2019, I announced my run to be the next U.S. senator from Kansas, and you all stepped up to join our team. In 2020, we’re going to win. Happy New Year!

Kansas already knew how this story would end. Now the country is learning that we can’t afford the GOP tax bill. Just like the failed Brownback tax plan, the federal tax plan created massive loopholes and giveaways for big corporations and the 1% — at the expense of working families. Now our budget deficit is over $1 trillion.
Washington is sick. Send a doctor to fix it.

On Tuesday, we’re closing the books on our first quarter. After that, our opponents will be able to see the strength of the grassroots team we’re building. Be a part of the campaign that’s going to get the U.S. Senate back working for Kansans:

‪It’s going to take a lot of money to build the largest grassroots campaign Kansas has ever seen, especially with Mitch McConnell and Kris Kobach committed to stopping us. Tuesday is our first public fundraising deadline. Let’s show our strength.‬
‪Kansans are overwhelmingly in favor of red flag laws. They’re commonsense measures that will save lives.‬

It’s such a blessing to be with loved ones this Christmas. My family and I spent the day catching up, playing board games (like Dixit!) and sharing meals. My prayer today is that all Kansans have the opportunity to do the same this holiday season.
Merry Christmas, Kansas!

"The tax cuts were never going to — and have not — come anywhere close to paying for themselves." Kansans are getting deja vu. It’s no surprise to us that this short-sighted tax plan didn’t work. We need to focus on tax cuts that help working families.

Too many people in Congress are there for the wrong reasons. They fight for extreme partisanship, not solutions. As a doctor, I know that the only way we can move forward is together — with an eye towards facts and evidence. I need you on this team:

In medical school, I was always taught to collect and evaluate the data for answers to public health questions. I'm glad to see Congress is finally getting serious about addressing the epidemic of gun violence in our communities.

I'm honored to be endorsed by 314 Action. As a doctor, I've always advocated for commonsense solutions — like strong public education, access to affordable healthcare and action to address our climate. That's what I'll fight for in the U.S. Senate, too.

The Kansas Republican Party leadership will stop at nothing to destabilize our healthcare system. They marched our state into a reckless lawsuit that could block support for people with pre-existing conditions, end coverage for children under the age of 26 and reopen the Medicare coverage gap any day now. Kansans deserve better than this uncertainty.
Unions helped create America's middle class and they're key to maintaining it. I stand with Kansas' working families in support of unions.

The Kansas GOP already tried an extreme tax experiment that our state couldn’t afford. Under Governor Brownback, it decimated the budget, hurt our economy, and caused massive cuts to our schools. Unfortunately, as predicted, it’s going just as poorly for the federal government.
Thanks to Brandon Whipple for introducing me at our Wichita meet and greet last night! It was great talking with folks about how we can bring healthcare costs down.

Kansas' healthcare system is falling behind and our children are the ones suffering. Yesterday on the Governor's Council on Medicaid Expansion, @dr_dianerowland told us that expanding KanCare would provide health AND economic benefits.

One year ago today, I changed my party registration and became a Democrat.  I’ll tell you the whole story: My parents were moderate Republicans in the mold of Kansas Senator Nancy Kassebaum. They taught me that Republicanism meant valuing public education, pursuing fiscal responsibility, and supporting governments that are close to the people they govern.  I’ve always believed that all people deserve the same rights, no matter their race, gender, or sexual orientation and women should be free to make their own reproductive choices — with whoever they choose to consult. Over time, I found the views of the Republican Party to be increasingly distant from my own. As a doctor, I advocated for commonsense solutions, not partisan politics. Meanwhile, the GOP rejected Medicaid expansion and comprehensive funding for public education. It had become clear to me that my values and my approach were no longer welcome by the Kansas Republican Party leadership, so I left the party and found a new home. A lot changed that day one year ago when I was welcomed with open arms by the Kansas Democratic Party — I got a new desk in the Senate chamber and joined some new committees. My party registration may have changed, but my values did not. I represent my constituents in Topeka the way I always have, and they have the same needs they’ve always had: affordable health care, quality public education, and accessible child care. I still work with the same colleagues and have the same relationships, on both sides of the aisle, as I always have. Red and blue must work together towards practical solutions based on scientific evidence and data, even in this deeply polarized era. I look forward to traveling the state and visiting with all Kansans regardless of their party affiliation. We have a bright future ahead of us. Together, we can make Kansas — and America — the best it can be. Now, let’s go win this race.
The USMCA moving forward is good news — we owe Kansas farmers and ranchers much more, though. We must end the administration's devastating trade wars.

I was excited to join Equality Kansas last night to talk about how I’ll continue to fight for LGBTQ rights in Topeka. This session, I’m sponsoring a bill to protect all Kansans from discrimination, no matter their gender identity or sexual orientation.
Join Mayor-Elect Brandon Whipple and me for some light refreshments and conversation in Wichita on Friday. I'd love to see you all there!
Great crowd at Tallgrass Creek earlier this week! Kansas needs an independent voice in the Senate. I talked about how I’ll fight to preserve Social Security and Medicare into the future.

We can win anywhere if we focus on the needs of our families. And that’s exactly what I’ve done throughout my career, both as a doctor and a public servant. I commit to putting the needs of our people first, before partisan politics. And together, we’ll make progress for Kansas.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2019/11/25/how-democrats-can-beat-trump-everywhere/#click=https://t.co/5JbwzPNbtt
Happy Thanksgiving from our family to yours!

I was happy to join the Linn County Democrats yesterday for their annual dinner. We talked about the challenges families face and how we can make a difference in the future of Kansas together. Thank you for the invitation to share my priorities for our state.
I was honored to speak at the AFL-CIO convention today. We must work together to support Kansas workers and strengthen the middle class. I look forward to being your partner.
I was pleased to join the Ellis County Democrats tonight to celebrate the 60th anniversary of President Kennedy’s visit to Hays. Thank you for the wonderful experience.

Despite trade policies from Washington harming the agricultural sector, Kansas farmers and business owners are doing what they have to do to open new markets and opportunities for Kansas exports. I'm proud of their efforts and will do all I can to make their voices heard and impact trade policy for the better. https://www.hutchnews.com/news/20191113/farmers-finding-news-avenues-for-kansas-wheat-overseas/1

I had a great time at the Wyandotte Dems’ monthly breakfast this morning. I am grateful for the stories people shared and the chance to share my vision for Kansas. Thanks for having me, Wyandotte Dems!

The trade policies with China has done nothing but harm our farmers, limit the markets where we can sell Kansas products, and further hurt our ag economy already challenged by drought and extreme weather. Kansas needs a U.S. Senator willing to listen to farmers and stand up to both parties to get things done for our state.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-30/u-s-farm-bankruptcies-surge-24-on-strain-from-trump-trade-war

Frankly, I’m the only candidate in this race who works across party lines. My concern is that some of the other candidates in this race have only ever been interested in working with their own party – and that mentality is exactly why Washington is so dysfunctional and why nothing ever gets done.  https://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/article236903973.html

Today we honor all who have served in the United States Armed Forces. These brave men and women put their lives on the line to protect our freedom and our way of life. I extend my gratitude to all veterans and their families today and everyday.

Following the elections yesterday, it’s clear we can win anywhere. People want change. It’s time for a voice of reason in Washington. Join our team today! https://secure.actblue.com/donate/bb4ks-social?refcode=tw116
‪Local elections are key to our communities and our state. Tomorrow is Election Day! Let’s all GO VOTE! ‬

Momentum is growing for our campaign for U.S. Senate. First Gov. Kathleen Sebelius and Gov. Laura Kelly joined the team and now EMILY's List and the Senate Democrats are supporting us. Let’s keep working hard!

I'm honored to have the support and endorsement of Governor Laura Kelly in this important campaign for U.S. Senate. We share a strong commitment to Kansas families and commonsense problem solving.Dr. Barbara Bollier shares my commonsense Kansas values and has a proven track record of standing up for our families. She is exactly the principled, independent voice of reason Kansas needs representing them in D.C. I’m so pleased to support and endorse her campaign for U.S. Senate.
“Expanding Medicaid is the right thing to do. It’s there to improve access to health care for Kansans, especially in the rural areas.” That's absolutely right.

I've been in this race for less than 2 weeks, but we've already heard from so many Kansans excited to get involved. Donate today and help us build the foundation for this historic campaign. https://secure.actblue.com/donate/bb4ks-web
Thank you to the workers of UAW International Union for standing strong and congratulations on reaching a contract agreement.

Time and time again, I stood up to Sam Brownback and his efforts to block Medicaid expansion. As a doctor and US Senator, I'll always work to make health care more affordable for Kansans. https://www.iolaregister.com/opinion/sen-barbara-bollier-strong-candidate-us-senate

I’m humbled to have the support and endorsement of Gov. Kathleen Sebelius in our historic campaign for U.S. Senate. Together, we can bring common sense back to Washington and put the best interests of Kansas families first.

We must do more to support rural Kansas. I've been working hard to find real solutions that make a difference for rural families, like investing in roads, broadband renewable energy, and expanding Medicaid. We may not be able to "turn back the clock," but we can support commonsense policies to help these communities find new life.  https://www.kcur.org/post/people-emptying-parts-rural-kansas-insist-were-not-going-let-them-die#stream/0
Endorsement alert: 23 Kansas legislators have endorsed my campaign for US Senate. I’m honored to have their support!
Thank you, Barry Grissom, for your public service and steadfast commitment to the people of Kansas. I’m honored to have your endorsement and support!

Since I announced my campaign for US Senate yesterday, I’ve heard from so many friends, neighbors, and fellow Kansans. Folks are fired up about this race. Are you ready to build this campaign and win this Senate seat? Let's get to work!

I became a doctor to help people. And I went into public service to fix things that were broken. I'm running to be your next US Senator to do both. As a doctor, I’ve never really been about partisan labels, just problem solving. And we need more of that right now. Instead of getting into political fights, I’ll focus on what matters most to families -- the cost of health care, child care, and how to save for retirement. Winning a Senate race in Kansas won’t be easy, but recent polls show we have a path. We can WIN this race, but we can’t do it without your help. Will you join our campaign? https://bollierforkansas.com

I was pleased to join the Ellis County Democrats tonight to celebrate the 60th anniversary of President Kennedy’s visit to Hays. Thank you for the wonderful experience.

Since I announced my campaign for US Senate yesterday, I’ve heard from so many friends, neighbors, and fellow Kansans. Folks are fired up about this race. Are you ready to build this campaign and win this Senate seat? Let's get to work!

I became a doctor to help people. And I went into public service to fix things that were broken. I'm running to be your next US Senator to do both. As a doctor, I’ve never really been about partisan labels, just problem solving. And we need more of that right now. Instead of getting into political fights, I’ll focus on what matters most to families -- the cost of health care, child care, and how to save for retirement.
